title: Smoking ban and high cigarette taxes is working as fewer teens take up the habit
text:
Smoking bans and higher taxes have led to fewer teenagers taking up the habit.
Teens who grow up in smoke-free environments are a third less likely to start smoking.
And people are less likely to breathe in secondhand smoke because there are fewer regular smokers.
Bans on smoking at work and in public places also made teenagers find the habit unacceptable.
The 11-year study by University of California researchers tracked 4,000 Americans aged between 12 to 18 as they grew up.
It found that those who lived in states which have banned smoking in bars were 20 per cent less likely to be smokers.
Stubbing it out: The smoking ban has led to fewer teens taking up the habit
The researchers argued further hefty increases in tobacco tax could cut the number of young people smoking by half.
Professor Anna Song said: "Because smoking initiation typically occurs before youth enter the workplace, smoke-free workplace laws likely affect smoking initiation by showing kids that adult smoking norms reject smoking."
For each 10 cents hike, the odds of someone taking up the habit drop by three per cent.
Professor Stanton Glantzsaid: "Our results suggest that the $2 tax increase being discussed in the California legislature would cut youth smoking initiation nearly in half.
The study which used data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics' National Longitudinal Survey of Youth 1997 was published in JAMA Pediatrics.
